I keep pressing the control knob when trying to press the shutter (they should be reversed).>>  3" screen>>  Dedicated movie button>>  Great quality video. One thing you need to be aware of if you burn DVDs; you cannot select the AVCHD on the FX setting (in the menu settings) unless you plan on burning to a Blu-Ray disc - they are that good!>> 20X optical zoom, which goes out to 40X in ClearImage and 80X in digital zoom. (Although I don't recommend going out to 80X digital, but 40X ClearImage isn't half bad.)>> Sony G Lens. I know some like the Carl Zeiss lens better, but my HX10V also has the G lens and I think it's superior.>>  EASY setting. Anyone can use this camera on this setting, it gives you very limited choices, easy enough for a Great-Grandma.>>  Special effects: Love the watercolor and illustration effects, which you apply in the playback menu, and it also saves your original photo.>>  Background defocus. This is my favorite setting, it has it's own position on the control knob. You have a choice of low, medium, or high blurred background, and with a little experimenting, you can get the same bokeh effect of a DSLR. I uploaded a photo of a flower showing this feature.Cons:>>  The battery charging door is flimsy and I don't see it lasting long. Better off buying a separate battery charger. I don't like charging the battery inside the camera anyway.>>  Does not have P/A/S/M full manual control. It should have for this price.>>  The tripod socket appears to be plastic; it's black so I'm not 100% sure, but when they are metal, they are almost always silver.One thing to note as it's the same on the WX80:  Don't get the HDMI cable connector on the bottom of the camera confused with the battery charging connector. I did get confused for a few minutes with the WX80 and I thought Sony had included the incorrect USB cable.Wi-Fi:  I had no problems with setting this up with my desktop PC which still uses Vista. Sony includes a separate pamphlet for Wi-Fi set-up. (I already had Play Memories installed from my other Sony cameras, so that may have made it easier for me).If your router has a WPS Push Button it's easy-peasy to set up (my Cisco Valet has the WPS button, but I'm not sure if other routers have this button as my only router experience is with Valets). After you have the PlayMemories software installed, you have to "one-time" connect the camera to your PC with the USB cable and set up the SSID/password. If you have the WPS Push Button, you press your router button first, then get into the Toolbox/menu on the camera and press Wi-Fi Push. It takes a few minutes to completely connect, but once you've done that, you're good to go. Once I tried the wi-fi, I haven't bothered again. It's slow. It drains the battery quicker. It's not worth the hassle.Like I said above, no camera is perfect. My HX10V has GPS, which I keep turned off as it drains the battery. The WX300 has Wi-Fi, but it's slow to use. I think my HX10V takes a little sharper photo, but it's larger/clunkier. My HX10V was made in Japan (and a little cheaper than this camera), while the WX300 is fairly expensive for not having full manual control P/A/S/M and it's made in China.  I've owned well over 50 cameras and haven't found the perfect one yet. If I ever do, that would be a 10 star camera!Sony HX10V: Sony Cyber-shot DSC-HX10V 18.2 MP Exmor R CMOS Digital Camera with 16x Optical Zoom and 3.0-inch LCD (Black) (2012 Model)Sony WX80: Sony DSC-WX80/R 16 MP Digital Camera with 2.7-Inch LCD (Red)See comment section below for a link to a more thorough User Manual.

Reviews.Title: A mixed bag -- containing gold coins, and a feral cat.
Reviews.Author: Kevin Nicholls "jaded, aging hipster"
Reviews.Content: Though typically a Canon devotee, I was on the verge of replacing a Sony Cyber-shot DSC-WX50 16.2 MP Digital Camera with 5x Optical Zoom and 2.7-inch LCD  (Black) (2012 Model) with a similarly-ranged Canon, when I had the opportunity to give Sony another try.The results were... mixed.The positives:+Image quality can be exceedingly good. I'm hesitant to say "rivaling a DSLR", but in the right hands, it's entirely possible.+20x optical zoom is pretty much as awesome as you might suspect. Want to see pores on someone's nose from 15 feet away? Here's your camera.+For as capable as this camera is, it's surprisingly light. Not pocketable, but not big enough to need its own gear bag.+With a decent card, write speeds are excellent.+Many, many image options to choose from -- though it's not likely you're going to use them if you're not prepared (see negatives).+Sony service is pretty great, if something goes wrong.The negatives:-While the automatic mode seems like a great feature, it takes FOR-EVER to decide how, if anything in the scene is in motion. It's infuriating, and no amount of hammering the shutter will cause the camera to actually take the picture. I thought this was a shortcoming in the lower-end DSC-WX50 and really expected improvement for a camera that costs this much money.-In spite of the vast array of modes and effects, Sony hasn't developed a very graceful way to get to them and switch between them. If you're composing a shot and know what you want, this probably isn't a big deal. But if you want to add a little tweak to something just for fun during a snapshot, you can pretty much forget about it.-Because Sony isn't as "common" as Canon and Nikon, there are limited third-party add-ons available.Under very specific scenarios, the DSC-WX300 can be a five-star camera. But, those scenarios are, more often than not, fairly pristine conditions composed by a photographer with some patience. As a "I'm carrying this in my bag / purse for spontaneous pictures of my kids / sporting events / tourist attractions", I'd have to say that the automatic mode makes the camera abysmal.If I was in the market for a similarly-spec'ed camera and didn't have my heart set on a megapixel number, I'd go with the superior Canon PowerShot SX280 HS 12.1 MP CMOS Digital Camera with 20x Image Stabilized Zoom 25mm Wide-Angle Lens and 1080p Full-HD Video (Black). If I absolutely needed higher resolution, then I'd have to say that the Nikon COOLPIX S9500 18.1 MP Digital Camera with 22x Zoom and Built-In Wi-Fi (Black) is the best choice for the same money.

Just a good demo of the zoom and image quality, plus handling the colors. All very natural and not too saturated.------Update: I've been walking around with this camera for a month. Taken it on several of my Urbex outings. My observations: The key to great photos is using the scene modes. There are a lot, from HDR to night handheld dark. I accidentally used "handheld dark" and "HDR" at the *wrong* times and received great results. From off to shooting a photo is about 5 seconds. The zoom still impresses. When I'm navigating tight spaces or climbing and don't want to (or can't) carry my camera bag or pack, this thing is great. For me, the zoom makes it. The pixel quality is lacking, but that's what you get with these tiny cameras. The battery life is amazing. I've filled up a 32 gig card three times on the same battery charge - and still not empty! Rugged? Not at all. It has to be in a padded bag. It scratches easily (but most things will when they come in contact with flaking bricks, rusting metal and the like.) I'm amazed at a the results shot in near total blackness!------I think Sony thought of every possible option. Smart phone/iPhone as a remote control? Check. "Easy mode" so when you loan the phone to Grandma the icons are simplified and a lot bigger? Check. BIG LCD screen? Yep. Stereo mic? Yes. Single shot 3-D photos? Check. Scenes, special effects, panoramic shots? Yes. Wi-Fi upload to a network or smart phone? Yep. Video quality up to Blu-Ray? Check. Advanced stuff like exposure compensation, 10 fps shooting, and program mode? Heck yes. Even different smile detection - slight, normal and big smiles?! Automatic trigger on smile detection. Face detection before shot. Detect TWO faces before shooting. Two steady-shot modes, in camera manual/help, 60i movie quality or MP4, 20x zoom plus additional digital zoom, red eye reduction - and lots more - including a huge screen!It's an impressive camera with a wondrous array of features. BUT, there are a couple of very minor issues. The cover on the USB port (connects to computer, charges camera, etc.) has a really flimsy design. I can see this coming off quickly. The little tab that keeps it in place is so short, it's difficult to plug in the cable. When zoomed in, autofocus tends to "hunt" - in tight focus - say 20x, unless the subject has a lot of contrast, focus may fail. This is typical of small cameras. The smart phone app is cool, but has limited features - it can't control any advanced stuff - just trigger the shutter, switch between movie and still photos, and zoom in and out. The zoom is clunky - it zooms in and out a little with each tap - so no smooth zooming. For stills that's fine - for video, it's choppy. Still, it's a great feature. I tested it with my Droid phone, Droid tablet and iPad 2.Apps are available for Droid and i devices. The interface is identical. Tools: Self-Timer- on/off, Flash- auto/off, review check- Review, save image/review only/off. First you turn on Wi-Fi on the phone, then select "Ctrl with smartphone" - it's that simple.iPad: Ran the app. Received an error: "Search the shooting device from the network setting of the terminal and set it" HUH? Turns out you need to join the network from the settings menu (settings->wi-fi) before using the app. Entered password, done.Droid phone (Motorola Bionic): Ran the app, entered password, done.Droid Tabled (Samsung Tab 2 10.1): Installed the same as on the phone. One problem - the QR code on the instructions was folded in half and small. The tablet could not read it, so I had to enter the URL manually, or optionally, just search the Play store.The camera streams to the device, so your tablet or phone displays a live image. Cool.You can't copy the video to the external device via wireless, and the images that auto-copy are reduced in size. You can manually transfer full sized images, but not videos. You need the USB cable for that.Other unusual features: The camera can play slideshows and video via HDMI, with music. You can transfer music to the camera from your PC for this. When you navigate to the camera from "My Computer" you'll see a link - clicking this takes you to a special Sony page for downloading various programs. Image conversion, music copy and more.WiFi: You need to install software on your computer to use WiFi?! This also also uses the Sony Play Online service - you get 5 gig of storage free. Download and install was pain free (Windows 7.) However, the software could not find the camera. Power cycled the camera and ran the software again. Still can't find the camera. This entire phone/wireless thing is more confusing than it needs to be. I want to connect via WiFi. The instructions say I need to connect the camera to the computer I want to connect wirelessly to. Or that's what I think it says. The grammar is so bad it's difficult to say. Maybe I should try Google translate? Nope - no kinda-English to English translation. Can't get the camera to communicate with the software. Tried numerous times and gave up. Tried Google - I typed out "play memories " and it autocompleted the "no camera found." So this is obviously a common problem. Reading through the replies, Sony always blames the computer. The camera DOES show up as an external device in "My Computer", so you can manually copy files. Spent oven an hour on this - never got the USB to work. I even found the option to setup the wireless network and did that. My camera logs into my network - but can't do anything?!? Figured I'd try again. Removed and reinstalled everything. According to the directions "Turn on your camera, and connect it to the computer." This launches the software. Nope.So let's try the in-camera help.... No good. It's basically "Have a problem, it's not the camera..." So I plug in the USB cable and.... this popped up when I attached the camera to the computer - "Information of the computer where the data is to be saved is not set to the device. Connect the computer to the device with an USB cable and set it." Really? Huh? What? I thought that's what I just did. I'll keep trying. One problem - Sony expects everything to work and provides no help when it doesn't. Anyway, my monster computer has four individual internal hubs. I was connected to a USB 3 port. Disconnected and plugged into a USB 2 port. That solved the problem. Ran everything, got wireless working. After all that, wireless just lets you transfer files to the computer. That's it. No options, no control. And it's painfully slow. Transferring a dozen images took almost 20 minutes. I have a FAST dual band wireless network. So the camera is the bottleneck. Convenience? Nice. Speed? Snail's pace. I can't find any information on the network speed, but I'm guessing 802.11b - the camera does power down after transferring the files.Messages: Had to laugh at some of these. The English is terrible, as bad as some stuff you'll find in poorly translated assembly instructions on Chinese lawn furniture.Overall this is a feature rich, compact phone with a huge battery life!If you're looking for a case/bag/pouch for it, the Lowepro Ridge 10 Camera Case (Black) is a perfect fit.Followup: I've used this little gem to shoot around 500 photos. The strong points: scene shooting and the zoom. I just added some more zoom samples. The quality from 1/2 a mile away is amazing!One final thing. People are claiming there's a design flaw or bug - nope. It's not a design flaw. It's physics. My $5,000 DSLR has the same problem. A long lens occults the flash, causing a shadow in the lower left corner (the flash is in the upper right corner). The only way to avoid this is to move the flash totally off the camera. Or use common sense and not use a flash when zooming 20X! With that zoom, you need good light, a stationary subject, steady hand - or tripod. The slightest camera shake (hand motion) is also magnified 20x! Once you're past 20 feet or so, the flash is next to useless - and drains the battery fast.

Reviews.Title: Best. Camera I've Owned
Reviews.Author: C28
Reviews.Content: I love this camera. I took it to Mexico on vacation and have the BEST pictures, very clear and the wifi function allowed me to load pics from my camera to my iPad daily so I could be sure to have copies on my cloud in case something happened to the camera (theft, damage). The recommended waterproof case doesn't fit the camera so be careful.

Reviews.Title: Consider another camera
Reviews.Author: Akaiya
Reviews.Content: Have had the camera about a month. good video, sharp pictures. Largest problem is the LCD screen. If you are in open sunlight it becomes impossible to see what you are targeting, but works well in shade. The reviews on this were ranting how great it was. You would think those reviewers would step outside occasionally to take pictures.

Reviews.Title: Great camera - love the wifi feature and zoom
Reviews.Author: David B. Little
Reviews.Content: Overall - this is a great camera.  Lightweight, easy to carry in a pocket, simple to use with great features.  We especially like the zoom and wifi capability.  Wifi allows me to connect with my i-Phone which allows me to view and upload pictures as-well-as take photographs via a i-Phone command - much better than using the built-in camera timer option where you have to push the button and then run to get into the picture.  Set up the camera and then send the command to take a picture while holding the phone!  Quality of the pictures are great and the zoom function is unbelievable.  I used the camera to get great pictures at my daughter's graduation - 150+ feet from seats to the stage.  Crisp pictures without blurring even at extreme distances.  Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Camera
Reviews.Author: Gossamer "Paul"
Reviews.Content: Before my trip to Peru, I was looking for a nice, compact camera in the $200 range.  I looked around at different manufacturers like Sony, Panasonic, Nikon, Canon, but ended up with this due to the price, size and features.  I like the Wifi sync feature, but to be honest didn't use it much since the image transfers can take some time if they are high quality images.  The 20x optical zoom is fantastic and probably the main reason I purchased the camera, since digital zoom is completely awful.  This camera is great in that I can easily carry it in my pocket if I want or the compact Sony case that I purchased with it.  The other cool thing I found was that it was pretty rainy in the mountains of Peru, but this camera handled the moisture beautifully.  I did keep it in a ziploc bag while not using to protect it, but it was exposed to the conditions when I took some pictures and it still works great.  I also like the fact that the flash is built into the camera and doesn't pop-up like others, which can easily break.It's definitely a good camera that I'd recommend to others.  I'll try to remember to post an update in the future to see if it's still OK after a year or two, since alot of these newer cameras don't last too long, but I have a feeling this one may last.

Reviews.Title: One of the Best Non-Professional Cameras!
Reviews.Author: Paul "wds"
Reviews.Content: Sony Cyber-Shot DSC WX300This is one of the best cameras for non-professionals.  The camera takes flawless pictures and the quality of Sony Lens G is uncompromised with that of Carl Zeiss Lens. The camera has different setting modes to suit your needs.However, please note that the zooming is not that powerful, I mean when zoomed to the 100% (all the way to 20x), the picture has grainy texture, not to a great extent, but to some extent.  If you want to take best images in bright area with sunlight or similar conditions, the Program Auto (P) works good.The pictures from the camera can be exported to computers or laptops or smartmobile devices that are directly connected to the same wi-fi router. What I mean by this is that if the computer has been connected to the same router using the ethernet cable, the export is not successful. In order to export the pictures to your computer, you may use the following guidelines:1. Download the PlayMemories software from the link: [...]This link will take you to direct download page bypassing all other pages.2. Installation of this software takes around 25 to 35 minutes depending upon the speed of your system. (Do not connect your camera to the computer using the USB cable before the installation of the PlayMemories software, this causes system crash.)3. Connect your Sony WX300 camera after installation of this software, and confirm the location.  That way the camera understands the destination location to export the pictures over the wi-fi.The battery has good backup capacity, way better than WX50.If you are a professional and would like to capture a butterfly with its original colors in sharp contrast for scientific purpose or aesthetic view, this is not for you. This camera is the best for vacationers for their everlasting memories.Thanks.

Reviews.Title: Wanted to love it, but just OK
Reviews.Author: Mary
Reviews.Content: I have a really nice Sony and wanted this as a purse backup on my trip to SE Asia. I used it about 3 times, didn't really like the quality of the pix, but now I have it in my car, so I'm happy. Can't keep my good camera in the car!

Reviews.Title: Very Good Point and Shoot Camera
Reviews.Author: David W
Reviews.Content: I would have rated this camera a four or five star if it was not for the quirky Wi-Fi mode.  I have a MAC computer and iPhone 5s and even with the help of Sony Customer Service I could enable this feature.  This was one of the reasons I purchased this camera in the first place.  This would have been a great feature if it actually functioned properly.  I was able to connect my smartphone and my phone registered the sony camera but the photo transfer would not function.Otherwise if you forget about the wi-fi function (pretend it does not exist...) it is a great little camera.Maybe a software fix will eventually address this problem down the road

Reviews.Title: Great camera... unless you want indoor close-ups of your kids
Reviews.Author: Lexie Pear
Reviews.Content: This camera took truly excellent pictures.  I used it for 3 months & loved all of the outdoor shots or groups of people.  However, I kept noticing that EVERY time I took a picture of my baby (which is why I bought & wanted a really great camear) there was a dark shadow in the bottom left corner of every image whenever I used the flash close-up.  I tried all kinds of settings and tried taking photos of flat inanimate objects to see if that helped... the dark corner was there every time.  Turns out, that teeny tiny flash is pretty powerful, but if you are up close to the object, a little shadow is cast when the light goes past the lens.  :(I returned the camera since the reason I bought it was for those close-up shots of my kid... and for now, that's mostly indoor too.One other quirk... I never discovered a way for the settings I chose to stay selected.  (I had to redo any settings I wanted every time I turned the camera off.)

Reviews.Title: Everything I wanted as an Upgrade....Almost!
Reviews.Author: papa diesel
Reviews.Content: Almost everything about this Sony is great.  Two items that come to mind are the image stabilization and the 20X zoom which set this apart from every compact point-n-shoot I've ever owned.  The quality of the pictures and videos are also superb.  But I agree with a previous review that criticizes the placement of the shutter button that should actually be where Sony chose to put the function selector dial.  You index finger just naturally gravitates to this position but instead of finding the shutter button, you find the function selector dial.  The shutter/zoom button is awkwardly located just inboard of the function selector dial.  It's a minor annoyance that requires you to train your muscle memory but it is also because of this feature that I could not give this camera 5 Stars.

Reviews.Title: Nearly perfect
Reviews.Author: Ron Graham "CJ-7"
Reviews.Content: The lens extends so far that it actually casts a shadow on your subject if it is closer than about 12-15 feet. I thought I was covering the flash with a finger until I tested it. Otherwise, it is the best camera we've owned and we buy a new camera about every 3 years. I also purchased a 64Gb card which was worth every penny. Battery life is excellent, zoom is phenominal.

Reviews.Title: Not Happy with Image Quality
Reviews.Author: Sunny
Reviews.Content: I returned this camera because image quality was not satisfying. Images had too much noise and were not at all sharp and clear.

Reviews.Title: SUPER SIZE for Travel , good WiFi, no shutter speed control
Reviews.Author: Bears Fan Jim "qm2-703"
Reviews.Content: XxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxA.  Size is amazing for a 20X zoom.B.  Indoor and outdoor colors are like Canon, which means more saturated, almost like Nikon and Lumix "Vivid".C.  Indoor exposures w/o flash, using Auto and Auto Superior are usually quite good. For social pics or PC monitor viewing, this camera is quite impressive for low light, getting good exposure with P mode at ISO 3200 and also with Anti-Blur Scene mode.D.  Video is very good. I have not yet tried to make any video longer than 6 minutes.E.  WiFi control of photos and videos thru my Samsung Tab 2 tablet is easy, after loading Sony Play Memories from the Google Play Store. Play Memories is a very small program and does not consume much internal memory, which is great. I did not get good results attempting to download PM onto my Nokia windows smartphone, however.Some weak points with this cam:A.  Focus is sometimes off in zoom past 15x. But in fairness, this camera is the smallest, therefore hardest-to-hold-steady camera with so much zoom.B.  Flash power is not adjustable. This could be a serious problem at closer ranges. But as I said above, P mode and Anti-Blur mode can give pretty good results at high ISO , so try those before you use flash.C.  It is easy to cover a portion if not all of the flash output window with your finger, because the tiny body leaves you having to be careful how you grip. A wrist strap is almost a requirement, because of the way you have to hold the camera by its edges.D.  Considerable noise above ISO 800. Under almost any degree of magnification, the results often look "speckled" or "blotchy". Be sure to use the zoom first, instead of trying to crop or magnify later.And now, my pet peeve:This camera is for "Auto mode" picture taking first and foremost. The WX300 cannot take "sideways" photos from a moving vehicle or amusement ride, etc. That is because there is no shutter speed control. (Yes, I still bought it knowing I would sometimes miss my manual controls). On the other hand, I have actually been able to get pretty decent outdoor stop action shots by using ISO 1600 in daylight.. Would never have to go this high with my cameras that have PASM modes.CONCLUSION:Size is great, 90% of still photos are very good, exposure and WB are very accurate, video is great but sound not so great, and that 20x zoom is very, very handy when it is held steady or there is a fast shutter speed used in good light.Actually I tried and liked the Canon SX280 with its PASM and adjustable flash power, even though it is a bit larger and heavier. But Canon is having a terrible glitch with video on the SX280's - I tried two, and they were both defective in their video. The other major pocket zoom, Panasonic, has by most reviews taken a step backward from the nice ZS15 and 20 models of 2012.So this Sony WX300 gets the edge as "best new travel zoom introduced during 2013" almost by default.

Reviews.Title: Good Camera
Reviews.Author: Abdul Qayum
Reviews.Content: Sony DAC-WX300/B 18.2 MP has all the characteristics required for personnel camera. The results are very good but the camera is vulnerable to shock.

Reviews.Title: it 's good camera
Reviews.Author: Chi Du
Reviews.Content: very nice and sharp pictures. But i try to send pictures to my TV, connecting to my TV via WIFI is not easy.

Reviews.Title: Good Camera
Reviews.Author: Jessica Young
Reviews.Content: I like this camera a lot. I'm not a professional photographer but I love to take cameras wherever I go and this one is the perfect size for a coat or pant pocket. I don't really like the position of the zoom button - seems too close to the settings button, but takes great pictures and great video. Would highly recommend if you enjoy an easy, good, dependable camera

Reviews.Title: Awesome!
Reviews.Author: Michael H.
Reviews.Content: Great camera for when I simply cant lug around my DSLR. Shutter speed is lightning fast. Solid construction so I'm not worried about throwing it in my pocket. The zoom works extremely well. It doesn't have the same amount of options that my DSLR has but lets face it, when I need to tweak things or swap lenses then I just bring my DSLR. This camera is for the shots you would have missed anyway because your camera is sitting at home.

Reviews.Title: Best Camera for my money!
Reviews.Author: Roger S. Bock "World traveler, adventure seeker"
Reviews.Content: The is a power house of engineering for outstanding pictures with long distance shots.  The lens magnification out performed the other cameras on display that cost hundreds of dollars more and is very compact and easy to carry and have at the ready to capture those action shots as they are happening, not after having to dig out a large camera from it's case with an equally long heavy lens attached.  The controls are well marked and easy to adjust or just leave it on automatic and still get great pictures.

Reviews.Title: Easy to use but tiny controls
Reviews.Author: shutterbug
Reviews.Content: This was a gift for my daughter, so I have not printed any photos, but I did set the camera up to work with my wireless Internet and synced it to my cell phone.  It was a fairly easy process.  It seems that it works well as long as you open up the app on the phone and then choose the pics from the camera to send.  Then you can share to social media from your phone, not directly from the camera.My only other comment is that the controls are very tiny, so if you have large hands, it may be a bit challenging, however the menu system is very straight forward and I feel like its a very user friendly camera even for a beginner to use.

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera
Reviews.Author: bwanc
Reviews.Content: I have had a lot of Sony DSC cameras and this is by far the best one yet.  Now, I'm no camera guru.  I still can't explain what an F-Stop is.  So from a typical casual user, this camera is great and easy to use.  It takes excellent pictures.  One of the big problems with prior cameras was picture blur from moving kids and pets.  I've tested this camera's ability, puposefully taking pictures of fast moving objects.  NO BLUR!!  The 20x zoom is phenomenal.  The picture was a little gritty in full zoom in some poorly lit interior shots, but crystal clear at full zoom in outside shots.  Maybe the F-stop thing has something to do with it?!?  I haven't used the Wi-Fi feature yet.  If you have to download 300 pictures, seems Wi-Fi isn't really feasible.  Another improvement is the mini USB charging ability. No longer need the special "Sony-only" charging cable!  Lastly, Sony is finally using a standard SDHC Memory Card.  No longer have to hook up that special "Sony-only" cable.  I'm not going to comment on all of the other special features, because this camera has already proven itself as a great, great buy.  Yes, I'm sure there are even better ones out there, but for the price this one is hard to beat.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera!!
Reviews.Author: Brett A.
Reviews.Content: My brother in law received this same camera for his BDay last summer and ever since, my wife, has wanted this to replace her 5 year old Panasonic.  The portability for all the concerts we go to will be great, the 20x optical zoom is amazing, especially for a camera this size.  I am not a camera geek so I don't know a lot about photography, but the price is worth it!

Reviews.Title: Great small camera
Reviews.Author: Bruce Fagley
Reviews.Content: Ordered this sony after our old cannon bit the dust. Small size takes some getting used to. Takes great pictures, zoom is especially impressive, we were at a show yesterday, sitting about 200' back from the stage and I was able to zoom in and take good low light pictures without the flash. Image stabilization works very well.  Many different "scene" modes, including a panorama mode that actually works pretty well.  A lot of features in a small package.  I was also able to use the WiFi feature to connect to my IPad and download pictures pretty easily.

Reviews.Title: Picture almost too bright
Reviews.Author: Reflection "Superwoman"
Reviews.Content: I must admit that I need to spend some time figuring out how to use this camera properly.  I've had it for a couple days and the automatic mode pictures seem almost too bright.  One the plus side if this extra brightness, I took a picture in the dark and the photo came out as though there was perfect lighting.

Reviews.Title: good purchase
Reviews.Author: BFJ
Reviews.Content: I juts bought this camera for my parents after my own purchase 6 months ago. I particularly like the optical 20x zoom which makes a great difference with electronic zooms. I like the light weight and the large screen on the back. Only one negative, i find it a bit slow to take a picture. I don't have any comparison so this is a feedback on an absolute basis. I would recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Fabulous Camera!
Reviews.Author: EnglishPen
Reviews.Content: My husband and I love this versatile, easy-to-use pocket camera. It is a powerful little device, and it is sleek and "pretty" as well (I got the red). The lens is amazing, and the pictures are stunning. Many of the pictures I took with this camera look as good as the ones my husband took with his Canon Rebel 35 mm. We are both delighted with this Sony camera's performance. I spent a few days getting familiar with it before we went on our vacation. A little time invested in reviewing the functions pays big dividends when you are ready to shoot. Nevertheless, if all you want to do is point and shoot without thinking about functions, this is a great camera for that too.

Reviews.Title: camera itself is excellent, but wifi and software need work
Reviews.Author: MCRC
Reviews.Content: I really like this camera- it's easy to use, takes very nice quality photos, has quick performance, a great zoom, and does reasonably well in low light. It has a built in flash where many of its competitors have a flash you have to manually pop up (which I tend to forget to do and end up missing the shot). But the Wifi setup was anything but easy to set up, and wireless transfer to my PC is disappointingly slow. I had quite a bit of trouble installing PlayMemories as well (it kept crashing until I figured out it wasn't compatible with some of my old cell phone pics- after I deleted them it worked fine), but I finally got it working, not that I'll probably use it much. Also, it doesn't take video at 1080p, only 1080i maximum.For comparison, I also tried the Fujifilm F900EXR. That camera's Wifi setup is easier and its wireless transfer is faster than the Sony's. However, the Fujifilm's picture quality is definitely not as good as the Sony's- it takes a lot of effort to get decent pictures with the Fujifilm, its auto modes just aren't very good (as I note in my review of that camera), whereas the auto modes with the Sony are excellent. The compact size of the Sony is also a real plus.So I think this is great camera for my needs, and the camera itself is what's most important, but the wireless functions and software setup could use some work.

Reviews.Title: Wow!
Reviews.Author: Caruchi
Reviews.Content: Excellent so far! Photos are amazing and wifi option is pretty convenient, I use it with my ipad and share photos almost instantly

Reviews.Title: Best in Class
Reviews.Author: Julian Scruggs
Reviews.Content: Best camera in its class...and a little outside its class. Wife took it to a Beyoncé concert and you'd swear she was a professional. The video and screenshots looked like something out of a magazine. Slides in your pocket, takes great Hi Def pics, and is easy to use.

Reviews.Title: like it
Reviews.Author: Sher
Reviews.Content: Good camera. Wifi helps. Nice zoom.  Pic quality is very nice. No blurs. Always handy because of its size. Like it

Reviews.Title: Great camera good price
Reviews.Author: Jason K.
Reviews.Content: Nice Little camera and easy to use...takes great pictures. would recommend to anyone who is looking for a new camera

Reviews.Title: COMPACT CAMERA WITH GREAT FEATURES
Reviews.Author: Rama
Reviews.Content: The Sony DSC-WX300/B Digital Camera is EXCELLENT. The 20x Optical Image is really Wonderful in such a Small Camera. The WiFi Feature is superb.

Reviews.Title: Incredible camera!
Reviews.Author: david penning
Reviews.Content: I first bought the Samsung WB150F...but was very quickly disappointed with it.  I was then looking at a few Canon models, especially because Canon always seemed to be at the top for point and shoot cameras.  But after trying this Sony out in the store, there really is no comparison.Pros:It has an extremely quick focusing time.  Even when taking videos, I don't lose my focus.  With other models it takes time to refocus, as you zoom in or out, but not this one!!The clarity of the pictures and videos is really amazing.  The effects that the camera offer are really great too!The camera offers an "advanced flash" that reaches farther than the normal flash - and I was very surprised with how well it worked.Incredible battery life.I really could keep going on in this section!Cons:Be careful when shooting really close macro pictures.  If the flash is on, and you try to get really close, you could find a dark spot on the corner of the picture when the flash hits the extended lens.There is no way to manually change - as far as my knowledge - the shutter speed.  But with the Intelligent and Superior functions, they do a really good job at trying to make it right.If you use Mac computers, you can't get the PlayMemories for your desktop.  You can still use iPhoto for your pictures, but if you want to record your videos in high quality, you have to use iMovie to import them.  Not a bad thing, but for people like me, I like to keep all my things in the same place (which means I then export my iMovie recordings to iTunes, then import that file into iPhoto and delete the others).If you're looking for the best point and shoot camera for $300 or less, this is it.  If you want to spend more, then you might as well move out of point and shoot models.

Reviews.Title: I cannot put it down
Reviews.Author: Dennis R. Smith, Jr.
Reviews.Content: I was a little skeptical about a 20 power for such a small camera. I took it to the beach and I could not believe how clear some of the telephoto pictures I took. I have been using it to photograph the hummingbirds in the back yard. I continue to be amazed at the quality of photo. I am not one for big expensive cameras so this is perfect. I have owned Olympus and Canon but this beats them both.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: titus
Reviews.Content: This is the third camera I have bought this year and the only one I have kept. Very user friendly; menu and features are simple and don't require a lot of time to get used to or figure out how to use. One thing that is a disappointment is the force flash. It doesn't flash every time. There is some type of auto setting that keeps it from going off, but if you switch the dial to a program setting you can force flash every time. My favorite feature is the video.  While you are taking HD, you can also snap still images!  Love that! And when you go back to watch the video, there is no pause or indication that you took a photo at that time.  It does take some extra time once you stop filming for the camera to write the pictures, but that hasn't been an issue for me so far. Clarity is another story. It's strange, I can take all the pictures I want from a moving car or even our boat and I can clearly see every drop of water, but if I take pictures of the kids playing in the house, they are a bit blurry with movement.  Still trying to figure that one out. Overall I am pleased with this camera and plan on keeping it for many years to come. I recommend it to those who want an easy to carry point and shoot. I always keep mine in my purse.  You never know when you're your going to need it.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera for casual use
Reviews.Author: CAD "CD"
Reviews.Content: This camera surprised me, it's tiny!  Tiny but powerful!  I bought this compact camera in the pretty red, for future international travel.  love the auto upload feature.  The software uploads directly from the camera to my laptop via a connection wire, so NO CD's!  I found the apps for the software in the Apple App Store which is awesome as the camera cannot be directly attached to an iPad or iPhone, so I'm in heaven.  The only thing is that I'm a little concerned about damaging the little thing as in the past I was used to using a full sized SLR. Big difference!  But it will fit into any little pouch in a purse or even a pocket.  I haven't tried the video yet but expect it will be awesome too if the rest of the features are any indication.  Battery has decently long life, but the true test of that will be the video feature as the camera is supposed to take up to 30 minutes of vid.  Bon voyage!

Reviews.Title: Great in low light
Reviews.Author: deneice zeve
Reviews.Content: So far it takes better than expected photos in low light, is stylish, small and easy to work.  Haven't printed out pictures but onscreen they look great.

Reviews.Title: The camera I've been waiting for
Reviews.Author: fastv8 "Home theater lover"
Reviews.Content: I had several criteria when upgrading my 2009 model Panasonic camera:a) The new camera must be small and light - my Panasonic was just too large and heavy and I was no longer willing to take it anywhere. The WX300 is PERFECT for carrying in your pocket. It's very small and very lightb) The zoom must be greater than 12x - in this case, a huge 20xc) It must be optically stabilized - The WX300 uses a lens mechanism to stabilize the video, not just image sensor shiftd) The battery life must be reasonable - The WX300 has AMAZING battery life. Even though I bought a spare battery, I have never needed ite) Video must be up to 1920x1080 - my old camera was 1280x720 maxf) The audio must be stereo with auto gain control - I go to a lot of concerts and the audio just gets blown out when using my smartphone - the WX300 has this and also a wind noise cut, although I don't have that enabledThere is only one thing that I was disappointed with and that's 3D photos. They just don't have any depth when viewed on my 3D TV. However, I didn't buy the camera for that, plus I had low expectations with a single lens device anyway.On the other hand, the panoramic pictures are VERY good once you get the hang of taking them.I took the WX300 to Mexico on vacation and shot more than an hour of video of a bay cruise. The video is BREATHTAKING when viewed on a large LCD TV. The quality has FAR exceeded my expectations and for this alone, I highly recommend the camera. I needed a decent point and shoot camera and have found it all in the WX300.

Reviews.Title: Long-time Canon user, very impressed with the WX300
Reviews.Author: Kevin La Ra
Reviews.Content: I am a long time Canon user, but I was getting tired of Canon not supporting 1080 HD video in their point-and-shoot cameras.  I know that the PowerShot SX280 now supports 1080, but the pre-release reviews I read put the Sony WX300 video ahead of the SX280.  And they are right.  Video is smooth. Exposure and contract are spot on.  Colors are rich but not over-saturated.  And the 20X zoom is wonderful.  The image-stability does as good a job as you can expect.  You can't fault the camera if you have shaky hands at 20X zoom.I bought this to take to Disneyworld instead of my Rebel SLR.  The WX300 is incredibly small.  The size and weight will be an asset when carrying it around all day.  And the 20X zoom will allow me to get the shots and videos I want of the kids on the rides.The user interface is very intuitive, if you have used a camera in the past 10 years.  This is nice, because the paper user manual is brief.  Sony is saving money by making the full user manual electronic.  But, so far, I have not needed it.  The menus and on-screen help is wonderful.  Sony has done a great job with the user interface on the WX300.The only thing I wish is that the micro-USB charging port was not behind the rubber cover on the right.  Since I am not going to buy a separate battery charger, I can see this cover coming off in a couple of years after repeated use.  The odd thing is Sony put the lesser used HDMI connection on the bottom, without a cover.The only negative I can find so far is the built-in flash over-exposes indoor shots.  This might just be on the built-in LCD, because the photos look a little better on my color calibrated PC monitor.  However, the fact the flash is built into the body and not a pop-up is nice.  You just need to make sure your right-middle finger is not in the way when pressing the shutterThe shape is VERY rectangular.  I am not sure if Sony could have added a little contouring without sacrificing functionality.I have only had the camera for a few day, so I have only had a change to try out the automatic modes.  Looking forward to updating this later.I just saw that Sony is coming out with the HX-50V - same sensor but with a 30X zoom lens.  Now I am wondering if I should return the WX300 for the HX-50.

Reviews.Title: Stay Away, Sony Customer Service is Terrible, camera doesn't last.
Reviews.Author: raesun23
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera about 6 months ago, worked great, then one day shutter started making a clicking sound and would not focus.  Still had a warranty, sent to Sony for repair, and they would not honor the warranty and tried to charge me $230 for repairs.  I only paid $250 for the camera!  That's a shame on Sony, thought they would be more reputable company and honor their warranties and provide a better product.  I will go back to a canon, at least they with stand normal day to day use and won't break after only 6 months.

Reviews.Title: Decent Point & Shoot
Reviews.Author: Joseph Spiegel "Joe"
Reviews.Content: Sony DSC-WX300/B 18 MP Digital Camera with 20x Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3-Inch LCD (Black)The first thing I noticed about the Sony WX300 and unfortunately other mid-level point & shoots is that they don't include an AC external charger with the kit. At around $300+ for these cameras, that's a cheap thing to omit. Still it was the first thing I noticed while unpacking and made me do a double take. I'm not deducting a star as it seems to be the way, now. What it did come with was a USB cable an AC adapter, a battery and a wrist tether. It's a very basic kit. There is also a quick reference guide and a link to more software and manuals on line.When you download and install the software you also get to setup the Wi-Fi on the camera to move your photos to your computer wirelessly. This took me a couple of tries to get going but once I got it right it is easy to transfer pictures to my PC. I'm running Windows 7. You bring up the menu and chose the Wi-Fi transfer and away the newest pictures go, super easy.  I've never had a camera that has this feature, they all should!In using the camera I notice it is smaller than my Lumix ZS20 Panasonic Lumix ZS20 14.1 MP High Sensitivity MOS Digital Camera with 20x Optical Zoom (Black). It is also lacking a good grip. There's a slight indentation where a good strip of rubber should be. Make sure you have the tether on your hand; this thing is too smooth for my taste. As for build quality, it's fairly typical of mid-level Made In China, plasticky cameras. It's all black (my color), with black switches and dials. The white and red models also feature this mono-tone look. My Lumix is black but has gray highlights and chrome dials switches and screws. To me it has the feel of a finer product, but that's my personal take. The Sony has 18 mega pixels four more than my Lumix, and delivers a very fine picture that you can really crop with that many MPs. Though, I did run into some issues with flash photography. I sometimes got a yellow halo around people. It might have been the surrounding lighting but I didn't see it on the rear 3" display, I noticed it on my 27" monitor at home. Over all I'm getting some good results and when I have a set of good example pictures I'll upload and comment on them. For video recording it can do 720p. Sony says Full HD 1080, but neglects to put the "P" on the end so in reality it's 720p or 1080i. My Lumix is 1080p.If video is a major selling point this is a strike. Many Sony cameras use Carl Zeiss lenses, this one does not. It has a Sony "G" lens, my Lumix has a Leica lens and system; yeah Leica makes me feel better. Same price point, the Sony should have had the Zeiss.The WX300 has a nice feature set such as plenty of modes for picture taking, panorama, HDR and enough auto modes to keep novices like me taking decent shots. My wish list for the "301" would be a better grip and GPS like my Lumix. Location tagging your shots is great especially if you're a traveler. It has the Wi-Fi why not GPS?  It's a nice camera and takes some really nice pics. I'm thinking my yellow ghost is an anomaly as I can't easily reproduce it. As I write this Amazon has it on sale for $280 in all three colors. They don't sell the ZS20 anymore and its price has skyrocketed to $400. At that difference the Sony has some real advantages. I think you'll like this camera but there are some really good choices in this price range.

Reviews.Author: Penny Murphree
Reviews.Content: After reading many reviews featuring compact zoom cameras, I ordered this model which was being rated as one of the top five.  The photos taken looked as if they were in a paint mode.  After resetting all features to factory default, it still wasn't correct.  I decided too that the menu was not very easy to negotiate so I didn't order another of this model.  My replacement is the Nikon S9700 with 30x zoom which I really, really like.

Reviews.Content: Had used it for a function at my house for the first time and decided to return it. Though the size is very compact and a good 20X zoom, the most important thing is the picture. This gives you a blur picture if there is a slightest movement by the subject. When you take pictures in the party, you cannot ask the subject to pose for the pictures every time. Take it from me, you cannot take spontaneous shots with this cam.

Reviews.Title: Worth every penny
Reviews.Author: Gary L Lovette
Reviews.Content: No where locally or online had as good of a price as Amazon. After extensive research online the DSC-WX300 is in a class all it's own. Best feature by far is the +auto which takes multiple pictures on different settings, combines the best features and creates an awesome photo.

Reviews.Title: SONY is improving but still has a few things to nail
Reviews.Author: RIK
Reviews.Content: I have tried SONY HX20V (and its predecessor HX9V), and this camera is an improvement over HX20V in that thei) Camera body is compacterii) Flash doesn't pop upiii) Battery life is improvediv) Charging position doesn't require camera to lie on the lens or LCDbut some old problems still persist and new ones have been addedi) Video's (AVCHD) have lines in the last frame when played on Windows Media Player on Windows 7 (there is no clean ending of the movie). This bug was introduced in HX20V (HX9V didn't have this problem) and SONY hasn't fixed it yet.ii) Panorama mode is still not as easy as with Casio's Exilim series. Sony gives you a fixed buffer that you have to fill in, instead of making a full panoramic picture based on when you stop, so if you don't fill in the full buffer you get black bars.iii) If you zoom beyond 4x and try to take a close up of a nearby item (ex. close up of nearby flowers using optical zoom instead of bending down) the camera won't focus. SONY's have had this problem along with Nikon but others like Casio Exilim series handle this scenario well.iv) The door to the charging unit is really flimsy and the connection between the power cord and the charging socket was very tight on my unit requiring a lot of force to unplug.v) Play button was a little too flush with the camera body, found myself pressing it a few times to switch mode. HX9V had poorly designed buttons which were fixed in HX20V and now some have come back.vi) Menu audio controls are not fine grain - so you can't turn off beeps during playback while keeping the beep feedback during focusing.Overall the camera is nice, takes good photos and videos, has fancy features like 20x optical zoom, HD quality video including modes for Blue-Ray discs, WiFi sharing, 3D pics, InCamera guide etc. in a very slim body. Compared to other compact superzooms that I have tried (Canon SX260HS, Sony DSC HX20V, Sony DSC HX9V, Samsung WB750, Nikon Coolpix S9100, Casio Exilim EX ZR100 and Panasonic DMC ZS19) I'd place this one better than all but the Panasonic. It's a different matter that Panasonic has taken a step back in it's "upgrade" to ZS19 with ZS25/30 which prompted me to take a look at SONY again.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Camera
Reviews.Author: Rahul
Reviews.Content: Its small and handy and works well when you have to carry light. great zoom, nice big screen and very handy.

Reviews.Title: Small and powerful
Reviews.Author: PK
Reviews.Content: I was going on my very first cruise and did not want my heavy Nikon D90 or my Canon 50x hanging around my neck all the time. I never considered a  Sony camera because of their proprietary memory card. I already had tons of SD cards. But I did want a quality small pocket size camera with a good zoom. I didn't want to rely on my phone because it seems I have to charge it every 5 min and I wanted something more reliable because I take tons of pictures. I was attracted to this camera in the the store because of the 20x optical zoom and found out that Sony cameras now accept SD cards. To make a long story short I used this camera all over on my cruise. It took great low light pictures around the ship, pretty sunsets, tons of selfies and high quality movies. I carried it in my pocket everywhere I went. The only thing I had problems with was the sweep panoramic zoom. I tried to use that feature when I was in the Smokies several weeks ago and kept getting a error message telling me that I was not moving the camera in the right direction. What!!??.  I just found out I was being too timid and not moving the camera quickly enough in the correct direction and it now works fine.The camera uses the standard mini usb cord to charge, but it is a little tough to insert the plug in the camera. That could be a better design.Conclusion:  I could not be happier with this camera and I am still surprised with its versatility and the quality of the photos. I carry it in my purse and use it all the time.

Reviews.Content: This camera is a great buy. You get fantastic image quality both in pictures and video. The audio is pretty clean as well. One thing I would highly suggest is buy a class 10 memory card. Most people buy a nice camera and go cheap with the memory card.

Reviews.Title: Takes excellent pictures

Reviews.Title: Thrilled!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Shopper
Reviews.Content: This camera exceeds my expectations. It was also a deal buying this through Amazon for $199, as these are $330 directly from Sony! Here's what I love about it:-Amazing clarity of distant objects using the 20X zoom.-Great automatic focus.-The ability for the camera to automatically detect & select the appropriate scene settings.-Well lit and clear flash photos, as opposed to some other cameras where it's nothing but glare.-The ability to photograph & film simultaneously.-Panoramic mode.-10-second timer option.-Rapid shot option. Reviews.Author: Steve S
Reviews.Content: I had an older Sony model, but it was about 3 years old.  It didn't have all the features (no panorama, WiFi connectivity, only 12 MP, 3x zoom etc.).  This camera is smaller than the older one.  I've only used it a few times, but the photos it takes are outstanding. I can't wait to try it in low-light settings.

Reviews.Title: great

Reviews.Content: Wonderful camera for a beginner. Very easy to use. Love the big screen! Love the feature that allows for auto - adjustment. Sometimes it takes a little long to process the pics tho, which means I have to wait to take the next pic. This is an inconvenience if you're taking live action shots.

Reviews.Title: All it claims to be
Reviews.Author: CB
Reviews.Content: This small camera is loaded with the features I actually use: large format captures, optical zoom, quick focusing, quick shutter, reasonably long battery life.  (I use photo manipulation software on my PC and so do not use those features on the camera.)  It is steady at full zoom and excellent in low light.  I purchased this smaller camera for a recent trip and I am very pleased with the outdoor shots in a wide variety of weather conditions.  Even more impressive is the light gathering capability in indoor areas where flash was prohibited or the space was too large for flash.  The loss of resolution in low light is minimal compared to other, larger, cameras I've used.One caveat:  this camera comes with no memory card and you'll want one.  I bought the 32GB Sony card and did not run out of space in a week's shooting.

Reviews.Content: I absolutely love this camera.  I strayed away from Sony point and shoots a few years ago and went with a Canon, bad move.  While I love my Canon DSLR, their compacts leave something to be desired.  This is a great camera, takes amazing pics and video.  Love it!!!!!!!

However, inside where the only light is from incandescent light bulbs, it isn't great. It isn't sharp at all and it is kind of noisy/grainy. To get around that, use the flash if you don't mind it looking pretty harsh.Overall, if you need a point and shoot for shooting outdoors, I highly recommend it. For indoors, like birthday parties or similar events, I would consider looking for another camera.Lastly, for $200, its a great deal. Sadly, I didn't know about this price on amazon and paid $280 at best buy.

Reviews.Title: love it!

Reviews.Title: Very good camera.

Reviews.Title: love it

Reviews.Author: noneother
Reviews.Content: I have been loyal to Cannon point and shoots for many years, but the last two I purchased, even though they were top rated, produced inconsistent quality and limited lifespans. This camera is higher quality by leaps and bounds over the recently purchased top of the line Cannon point and shoot camera it is replacing. This camera consistently results in amazing photos that are reminiscent of my high end Nokia DSLR. The setting selections on this camera are vast, and it is very easy to fine tune photos on the fly, resulting in amazing shots time and time again. The camera is compact, yet feels very solid, and time between shots is very brief. Built in settings are very powerful and easy to use, and the  WiFi feature is a nice plus. In my opinion, the best feature is the setting that adjusts the image when the natural light is coming from behind the subject. With any other camera the subject would become dark and your photo would not be usable, but with the setting on this camera activated, you will get a perfect shot regardless! Not to mention, the camera is absolutely beautiful in the white finish.

Reviews.Title: compact and light
Reviews.Author: D. Ingwerson
Reviews.Content: I had a previous cybershot that I loved. This one is smaller and lighter but has a stronger zoom. Very easy to carry in my purse.

Reviews.Title: So good even a 9 year old can take great photos!

Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for the whole family but it is used mostly by my nine year old, who wants to make movies when she grows up. She was able to figure it out in no time. Reviews.Title: GREAT camera!

Reviews.Title: I shopped til I dropped

LOVE IT>

Reviews.Title: Sony DSC-WX300 camera

Reviews.Title: Nice camera

Reviews.Title: Great gift for my boyfriend!

Reviews.Title: Great cam for it price!

Reviews.Title: Nice little camera.
Reviews.Author: Zman "coffee-nut"
Reviews.Content: A well built quality camera at a reasonable price. It's small enough to fit in a pocket, but not too small to handle. There are only two problems: Indoors the flash tends to leave a shadow behind your subject; and you have to be careful not to cover the flash with your finger.

Reviews.Title: Video Test in Review!
Reviews.Author: Paula Arango
Reviews.Content: [...]These are a view videos I have taken with my Sony Cyber-shot DSC-WX300. It's really small but a great camera. Works great in low-light and takes awesome pictures and videos!

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Jayne S
Reviews.Content: I love this camera. Has a built in flash that I seemed to keep putting my finger over the first dozen or so pictures untill I got used to it. You also have to down load a program called PlayMemories in order to save pics on you computer. Since I have an older desk top, it would not read the memory card and would not accept the USB cable, I'm not sure why. The card did download on to my lap top w/o problems. I'm not fond of the PlayMemories program but the camera it's self is great. I've always had Sonys and this one is by far the best. The zoom is wonderful and the movies look good. Fairly easy to use as I'm used to the Sony controls and nothing much has changed. There are lots of setting for differnt types of pictures and lightings. The in camera user guide is a big help too. Would recomand this camera to others even if it's your first.

Reviews.Title: sony dsc wx300
Reviews.Author: CEDRIC B. WILLIAMS
Reviews.Content: Because of the quality of the product. And I'm highly pleased with the speed of the camera and the precision of photos it produces.

Reviews.Title: great camera!
Reviews.Author: Martin Pera Cecchi
Reviews.Content: Great camera! Handy but good quality pictures. Also, the wifi function is easy and quick. I was travelling wituout my laptop and could download all the picts on internet through my cell phone. Really practical!

Reviews.Title: Overall, I love this little camera!
Reviews.Author: Zellie
Reviews.Content: I was playing around with the point and shoots on Black Friday in the Sony store and I wanted to get another CyberShot. I've had them in the past and as time went on I shifted to Canon. But I love how well these take pictures in low light situations so the husband and I decided on this one. I got mine for $250, which I would had gotten a better deal on Amazon for them... oh well, it's worth what I spent!I love how clear this camera gets with the 20x zoom. If you're familiar with Disney World; we were on the balcony of The Contemporary Resort watching the fireworks and my husband was able to snap a close up picture of the castle with Tomorrowland in the corner making it look like we were IN the park. It's insane how close and how clear the pictures get with this zoom! Even when you're recording a video, the zoom gets up really close and clear. Obviously stabilization is going to be tricky due to being up so close but you can see the camera stabilization go to work quickly! Speaking of, I have a hard time walking and talking and keeping my hand still while vlogging which caused my Canon to be SUPER shaky. But with this camera, you can barely tell! Also, by far the best point and shoot I've owned that takes amazing clear videos during fireworks, just sayin.Another thing I really like are the photo setting options. I don't remember all of them off the top of my head, but there's so many to choose from! I love how small and compact it is, it slides perfectly into my tiny purse and fits perfectly into my husbands pocket if I'm too lazy to put it away.The thing I DON'T like about this camera is that you can't simply insert your memory card into your laptop and drag and drop your files, you have to go through a program that's pre-loaded into the camera and set it up. It's a nice little program, but sometimes I'm in a hurry and would rather have the ability to just drag and drop my files onto my desktop. Another thing is that the numbers on the videos/pictures sometimes break away/reset. So it'll say 1/4 instead of what number the actual file is which makes it a little complicated when you're transferring files to remember WHERE that file is.Another thing that sort of annoys me is that I can't manually select the macro function while taking pictures. Reviews.Title: Great picture quality and zoom - not to great extra features and menus
Reviews.Author: eyecore
Reviews.Content: This is my second Sony camera, my first one being my current "go-to" camera, the Sony Cyber-shot DSC-TX200V 18.2 MP Waterproof Digital Camera with 5x Optical Zoom and 3.3-inch OLED (2012 Model).This camera, having a tremendous zoom, was intended to replace my somewhat aging Panasonic SuperZoom camera that's 12 or 15MP, but whose pictures are still clear and overall great quality.  This Sony camera DOES outdo the Panasonic in a couple areas:  The zoom is better, the pictures are higher megapixel, but both look about the same (great)...but low-light pictures actually look better with this Sony than the Panasonic with a larger lens.  So, overall, it's a better camera and it fits into a pocket, making it much better - I don't want to carry around a camera bag anytime I want to take a good quality picture.Some other features, such as the WiFi functionality is a lot less impressive.  The theory is you can upload your pictures to your computer or online service immediately.  I found that functionality to be confusing to use, and takes some time figuring out how to set things up, and even then it doesn't like to work very well.  (It sits there telling you that your WiFi is connected...but is in a "busy-wait" type of screen.)While I usually don't install software from companies selling me hardware (outside of required drivers), I did go ahead and install the picture software included here.  While I did uninstall it (because I manage my pictures differently), the software IS quite high quality, much like all Sony software I've used (like SoundForge and Vegas.)  To bundle software with hardware, Sony does NOT take the HP route of hiring some poorly educated programmers that get paid based on the number of lines of code they write, regardless of quality.  So that's a big plus in my book...Alas, the reason I mentioned that this is my second Sony camera...between the two, my other one is waterproof, touchscreen, and has a 5X zoom.  This one is not waterproof, has dials and multi-purpose buttons, and, quite frankly, requires a bit of learning to figure out how to make it do what you want it to do.  That's the reason for the 4 stars rather than 5:  my other Sony camera is VERY intuitive to do anything I want within the menus -- this one isn't; in fact, it's less intuitive than the Panasonic its replacing.Overall, a great camera with an awesome zoom that takes great pictures and videos...recommended, but don't buy it the day before you need it for great pictures, because you'll need some time to get familiar with it.

On indoor photos of people, sometimes there is a strange orange cast to the entire photo.  This could be caused by the type of lights used in the setting but who wants to fiddle with going to the camera's menu to take a quick group shot in a restaurant?  I love the size of the camera but, woefully, prefer my older Sony point and shoot with only 10x zoom for better photo quality, especially for taking photos of people.  Also, as mentioned by other reviewers, there is no dedicated macro mode.  This little beauty isn't as great as you might think.  Buy something else unless you're okay with mediocre results. Reviews.Title: Best camera for the size
Reviews.Author: Ardeal "Emi"
Reviews.Content: I have not seen a camera that takes better pictures and is as small as this one. With dimensions 96x55x25mm, or roughly 1 inch wide, it can easily fit in a pocket, yet it does not sacrifice on the huge size of the viewfinder. I have looked at another few Sony cybershot cameras, and I like the High Quality (Huge file sizes though) Panoramas from this camera the best, even better than that from the pricier HX-300. Video is OK. I have not used the 3D photo settings, or the Wi-Fi.This is a fancy point-and-shoot camera. You want a camera like this one to be reliable - no blur or motion issues. Image stabilization is great. The Intelligent Audio settings are probably the best setting to keep it on. One of my favorite settings is the Landscape with HDR setting for outdoor photography, as it takes multiple shots and combines them, to give out the best exposure in both well-lit areas, and shadows. Only issue with this HDR setting - make sure you or the subject does not move for about 1-2 seconds. And another favorite -  you have to try the 10 fps continuous shooting feature. I like to use it on my son doing flips while jumping in the pool.Potential issues with this camera: placement of the shutter release button (this is a cybershot - so it has to have the cybershot dial for the settings at the far end), fragile (nice metallic touch, yet does not seem to be shock-absorbent).Battery life is great with 500 shots per charge, unlike many compact cameras I've seen at Costco that have around 150-200 shots per charge. For around $20 you can buy additional no-brand batteries from Amazon, yet don't expect the same amount shots per charge.One last thing - I purchased a camerabag from a local store specifically for SONY WX cameras and it turned out too big, especially regarding height. Make sure you check out the dimensions, as the camera does not come with a camera bag.

Reviews.Title: Strong contender and good alternative to Canon S100/S110 series
Reviews.Author: J. Gitzlaff
Reviews.Content: I really enjoy using this camera.  Well-manufactured with good fit and finish, strong image quality, long zoom, good auto focus speed and responsive shutter.  It includes some more advanced features like WiFi hotspotting (though I think most people will be frustrated the first couple of times they use it, because it takes some getting used to how to setup and configure networking functions).  And as usual, Sony's menu control system is a little more complex than it needs to be when compared to similar cameras by Canon, Panasonic, etc., but I've used so many Sony cameras now that I'm getting used to this issue.Fundamentally, the DSC-WX300 is Sony's answer to Canon's superlative S100/S110 line of compact cameras, and I think it should appeal to the same kinds of users: (1) the casual photographer looking for a compact, jack-of-all-trades point and shoot with good image quality, and (2) the more serious enthusiast who wants a pocketable camera with a big zoom when they don't want to lug a larger SLR or interchangeable lens mirrorless camera kit around.The rear LCD screen takes up most of the camera body.  IMO, it's likely to be a major scratch and crack risk if you aren't accustomed to taking good care of your cameras.  If you  often drop yours in a backpack, purse, drawer, etc., with other things, you might want a screen protector.  I bought the cheap but excellent GGS Optical Glass LCD Screen Protector 3 inches for Digital Cameras, which fits perfectly, and couldn't be more pleased with the result.

Reviews.Title: Good for basic use, but limited in controls
Reviews.Author: J. Maxon
Reviews.Content: About a year ago, I kicked off my pursuit of being a hobbyist photographer (nature oriented). Because I was new to the field and had a low budget, I started off with the Panasonic Lumix ZS20 14.1 MP High Sensitivity MOS Digital Camera with 20x Optical Zoom (Black). I enjoyed the features and abilities that came with this camera, but as a point-and-shoot, I found it restrictive (such as the lack of RAW support) and wanted a more professional solution.So I returned the ZS20 and bought a Canon EOS Rebel T3i.I've been shooting with the T3i for a year now, and just recently upgraded to a Sony Alpha SLT-A99V. Both these cameras offer a wide range of professional tools, but I found myself missing the ZS20. Not because it was better in quality or features, but because there are times I don't want to lug a big SLR/SLT around.Of course, I can always use my cell phone, but the quality just isn't there. My phone is a Samsung Galaxy S II, which touts an 8+ megapixel picture capture. But there's no zoom beyond the digital pixel stretching, and the tiny image sensor does little to support high quality images.That's what makes this Sony DSC-WX300 a great option. Not only does it have a 20x zoom (a real zoom, not pixel stretching) and 18 MP (4896x3672px) image resolution, but it comes with a quality G lens.Sony's G lenses are similar to Canon's L lenses, which are typically only seen seen in digital SLRs and high-end camcorders. But this compact point-and-shoot gives you top of the class glass.That said, I was disappointed with the amount of ISO noise that appeared even in lighted conditions. On top of that, there are very few control options. No shutter or aperture priority modes, so no ability to do things like smooth flowing water, increase shutter to decrease ISO noise, or tweak depth of field for background blurring. There is a background blurring mode, but I find it to be both quirky (says it won't work half the time, but not why it won't work) and inadequate (not a strong blur). But the biggest annoyance is the lack of a good sports mode. Most of the pictures I took of my daughter displayed motion blur of some sort. There is an option in the camera that takes multiple pictures and ties them together to limit motion issues, but it's slow and not nearly as effective as a fast shutter setting.The nice thing about the Sony DSC-WX300 is that it's small and lightweight. It's simple and good for very basic use, but if you don't mind a somewhat larger point-and-shoot, I'd absolutely recommend the latest Panasonic Lumix ZS model instead.

The camera itself is light and easy to use for the most part. The large lcd screen is great to shoot photos and to review them as well. The zoom is great and the quality of prints coming out with this camera are superb. My favorite part is the wifi sharing aspect. No need to purchase any wifi sd cards. No need to plug this camera to your computer. Overall the camera is awesome. Easy to use and lots of great features.

Reviews.Title: Can a camera be too small?
Reviews.Author: cait
Reviews.Content: Yes, I think it can and this one may well be.Yes, it takes great pics and the image stabilization seems quite good from what I can tell so far. Lots of bells and whistles as is so common these days. Honestly, I think a lot of them are gimmickly and I will never use them, but if that is something you enjoy about a camera, you will find quite a few here. And the screen is a very nice size.But...First, this camera really does not have a very solid feel. I compared it to my Canon 260sx, which in comparison is like a little tank.Will it hold up over time..I have my doubts.And that little plastic door to the cable port...oh, I can see that breaking off very quickly. Which also ties into the fact that I HATE charging the battery in the camera. Yes, I can spend an extra bit of money and buy a freestanding charger, but I hate to have to.Is it just me, or is the shutter button in the wrong place? I find having to glance at the top of the camera to find it. Not a huge issue, but odd.The biggest problem however is that I really find this camera just a bit too small.I am a woman, with medium sized hands, and the buttons on this camera are more than a little trying. The on/off is tiny, the dials hard to really get a feel for. I have to use my finger tips. If I have an issue, I can see someone with bigger hands and fingers, like most men, will really have an issue.Great size to slip in a pocket...but once you take it out to actually use it, not so much.For the money, I think there are better options out there to buy.

Reviews.Title: A capable little camera (with some flaws)
Reviews.Author: Ravenhurst
Reviews.Content: I received my MX300 recently and immediately set out to take a bunch of photos and see if all the hype about this little camera had real legs. Tentative conclusions follow:PROSSmall size, very light, can be carried without the slightest effortSeemingly robust construction - looks sharp in blackImage quality very good (and often excellent)Crisp video with great color and detail - very professionalUseful pre-set functionsExcellent battery lifeCONSWiFi won't work despite hours of testing and seeking solutions on the InternetCamera won't be recognized by Toshiba PC running Win 8 so that you can move images to PC storagePlayMemories software buggy and often inoperative - I wouldn't recommend using it although without it you cannot transfer Movies to your PCConfusing menu structure - functions referred to in manual do not exist on camera menu (e.g. USB Settings under Main Settings)No obvious way to return to main menu once on sub-menuSony should revise the main manual and make it one for "dummies" (most manuals of course are written with co-pilot list readers in mind. Poor civilians are left to their own devices).Also, if you have large hands the camera's mini size may be an issue; I have medium-sized hands and the problem still exists, although after a while placing your fingers becomes instinctive.PS: I discovered how to make the laptop "see" the camera: unplug the power cord and THEN plug the camera in via USB. WX300 appears magically in My Computer. WiFi still a mystery.PS1: I upgraded my rating to FOUR stars. I am taking the WX300 along on a long trip as the only camera in the bag.

Reviews.Title: Good pictures but has drawbacks.
Reviews.Author: Clifford G. Giltinan
Reviews.Content: WAY WAY to small and slippery to hold onto comfortably.  It is almost exactly the same size as a deck of cards, minus the box.  Use the wrist strap or keep a spare $250 nearby.  Shot selection options are confusing as to what they do.  Pictures look the same to me in several different configurations.  The built-in instruction manual is totally worthless.  For example, the little green camera setting reads "Intelligent Auto... Exposure adjustment with automatic settings".  The little yellow camera setting reads "Superior Auto - Shoot sharp image reducing blur and noise automatically".  Did you get that?  Does 'Superior Auto' trump 'Intelligent Auto', or do I have that backwards?  Needs a blue camera setting that does both, automatic and sharp.  Optical zoom (best) does not pause as it zooms past x20 into digital (not so clear)zoom.  It is almost impossible to get max optical zoom without crossing the line into digital.  I still have not figured out how to kill the flash when I want.  Video is outstanding!  Get something bigger so you can find it and hang on to it.  I regret buying this camera.

Reviews.Title: Only charged twice before the micro USB port failed.
Reviews.Author: M. Chadwick "Just a reader"
Reviews.Content: It does NOT come with a battery wall charger.  It comes with a USB charger that connects to the camera via micro-USB cable.  Not the standard micro USB that works with a phone or other Sony cameras, but an extra small, mini micro cable connection that is very touchy.  Now after two chargings, the USB connection no longer works. The computer recognizes it as a device, but it won't charge through the computer or USB wall charger.I had to order a battery wall charger for $10.  What a pain in the butt.The camera takes nice photos, but what does it matter if you can't charge it?
